div.p: San Fernando Rey de España Misson represents the origin of the Spanish urban form in San Fernando. Mexican Independence in 1821 disrupted administration and communication to the territories in Alta California. The secularization of the missions allowed Mexican elites to purchase large tracts of land for agricultural production and cattle grazing. These characteristics provided the foundation for American suburban development which occurred following the American-Mexican War of 1848. The ceded territory of California was a big attraction for anglo expansion. In 1847, Charles Maclay and George Porter formed a partnership and purchased 56,000 acres of former mission land(Wanamaker, 20). This land acquisition designates a formal transition to the suburbanization project of San Fernando Valley. San Fernando’s development in the 20th century was characterized as an “agriburb” an economy based on agriculture products such as citrus and olives that required Mexican migrant labor.

note.placeName: San Fernando Rey de España Mission
note.p: San Fernando’s suburban development began due to the secularization of the Spanish missions and the purchase of mission land to American settlers.
